content: @WG-async-sprint-planning reminder that our sprint planning meeting is in ~25 minutes
@WG-async-sprint-planning howdy
Leave a :wave: so we know you're here
Let's start by updating the last sprint in the doc
Hey, I can't make it today, got a work meeting. I'll update the doc later. Nothing interesting to report.
@triagebot end-topic when you're ready

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
okay
Sprint retrospective
any thoughts on how the sprint went?

I finally have a local fix for #87613. Sadly enough, so much of my earlier confusion was due to me not thinking hard enough about how parsers work, and what the "current token" means in the middle of a parse.
but anyway, I should have a PR up later today.
I again didn't make as much progress as I hoped, though I should have anticipated that because we had performance reviews at work
We did pretty well @tmandry on our goals; not sure how we could've scaled them back. We almost made it to first draft...
@eholk and I made good progress on polish issues working together
I too over-promised; I didn't make any progress on debuginfo tooling stuff
but I'm hopeful that now I can put this polish issue down that I'll be able to attack debuginfo with gusto
I felt like I made a little progress on most things I'd planned, but not as much as I had planned
I'm super excited y'all for the RPITIDT work that @tmandry and I did :)
I saw in a different topic that @tmandry raised the question of whether we should have longer sprints
also excited to have YAAA (Yet Another Absurd Acronym)

pnkfelix said:

I saw in a different topic that tmandry raised the question of whether we should have longer sprints

(the motivation being to repurpose this time slot sometimes for something else)

nikomatsakis said:

I'm super excited y'all for the RPITIDT work that tmandry and I did :)

I do think we made good progress there :)
I wanted to take people's temperature about that.
YAAAAAA (Yet Another Absolutely Abtruse And Absurd Acronym)

pnkfelix said:

I wanted to take people's temperature about that.

on what, sorry? :)
I'm busy trying to add A's to my acronym

pnkfelix said:

pnkfelix said:

I saw in a different topic that tmandry raised the question of whether we should have longer sprints

(the motivation being to repurpose this time slot sometimes for something else)

^
hmm.. the 2-week sprints worked pretty well early on, but it seems like the actual pace has slowed down a bit since then
but I personally suspect the 2 week cadence is still necessary
Would we move sprints to three weeks or four weeks then?
its hard to retain mental context over longer periods
(as someone watching others, that is)
I do like the 2-week sprints
I also want to do the reading group
I don't know how to balance that :)
I mean, I'd be ok adding a bit more time
it will come out of my allocated "async budget"
oh, we could do the triage meeting less often?
that may not need to be weekly
I think doing the triage meeting less often makes sense.
s/more/less?

nikomatsakis said:

s/more/less?

Yes
We tend not to have a lot of issues to triage, so I think the meeting is more like a mid-sprint checkin
yeah we could repurpose the triage meeting slot. my only concern would be that 30 minutes might not be enough for the reading club
And by Monday I doubt we'll have much to report for this sprint
agree on 30 min might not be enough, depends
I imagined we would pick a blog post or other topic and read
and then just have general chat and discussion afterwards
and we'd have a queue in a hackmd
that people can add to
at the end, we pick something for the next week
(the idea though is to read it during the meeting, that's part of the point)
and the thing in the list can be anything publicly published somewhere
e.g. blog posts, explainers, etc
I wonder if we can extend to 45 min (and take a bit from our normal time slot @nikomatsakis)
wfm
and/or start earlier
you west coast people are lazy, 8:30am
I mean I prefer not to really start earlier on a monday, but if the other thing doesn't work for people's schedules I would survive :)
but what a great way to start your week
Either probably works for me
anyway, yeah, either wfm
I know for sure earlier works, and going longer probably works too
okay.. let's tentatively extend the slot to 45min every other week(?) and do reading club then
(i probably wont be able to attend due to a 15min standing meeting at 2022-03-07T11:45:00-05:00 I have, but its not a big deal to me.)
that is not the correct time
the zulip time selection widget is very annoying in how it handles am/pm
attempted to fix my time
(I'm not clear on what the starting time under discussion actually is. 2022-03-07T11:30:00-05:00 ? )
yeah
okay. Anyway, its no big deal. (Or if I decide I need to come, I can pretty easily jettison the standup)
I guess you technically have a conflict with the triage meeting slot already
that's right.
hmm, I'd like everyone to be able to come
but I haven't seen it as a priority for me to attend the triage meetings
(which maybe means i misunderstood something.)
in any case, how should we plan the reading sessions?
https://hackmd.io/6kSbmyggT6eAy5uvdB6srA
working on that already @tmandry
Would this be starting Monday or waiting a week or two?
@nikomatsakis do you normally do these over video?

eholk said:

Would this be starting Monday or waiting a week or two?

I don't really see a reason to wait :)
Sounds good to me
It looks like we have plenty of things to read already anyway
feel free to add things to the doc
hopefully the structure is self explanatory

tmandry said:

nikomatsakis do you normally do these over video?

^
Oh, I was going to propose Zulip
I like the idea that we can link to the thread
but I don't really care
I guess the zoom would permit more open-ended chat, maybe? not clear
okay. zulip is probably fine
@pnkfelix if we extended earlier to start at 2022-03-07T08:15:00-08:00, would you be able to come then?
for 30min, yes
(it would still be a 45 minute slot, so you would miss the last 15 minutes of that)
okay
let's try that :)
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.

I propose we start with

URL Added to list by Why?
Async cancellation 1 nikomatsakis I want to read it :)
for the first week :)
sounds good to me, I want to read it too :)
just because I've had it on my list 4eva
ok
ok, I think we can move on
Polish issues
oops, let me make the new sprint in the doc
okay, now we can add these
@eholk where we at with the stuff we were looking at
Huh, my hackmd is not syncing the left and right pane anymore
you could be editing the template (collapsed)
can you send the doc link again
https://hackmd.io/gPgXC4fsTZOgOnd-Bwhoag?both#2022-03-03

tmandry said:

you could be editing the template (collapsed)

Oh, that's it. Thanks!

nikomatsakis said:

eholk where we at with the stuff we were looking at

There's still an open question around what's the right thing to do with autoref: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/94309#discussion_r816359331
I'm thinking --
I've been reading the borrow checker section of the rustc dev guide to get more background around intersection regions too
there's a kind of hacky fix we could do
that would fix that intersection region problem more easily
basically changing the async fn desugaring
to introduce a named region that is outlived by all the others
definitely a kludge but maybe ok until we have polonius :)
Huh, I guess that'd be basically the same as the intersection region
it doesn't cover the impl trait use cases
But that also means there's a workaround for impl trait cases
we could add a region like that to -> impl Trait desugaring too
it won't work for TAIT
but .. yeah, workaround
(what calendar is the "async triage" meeting defined in?)
That approach definitely sounds easier..
@eholk well, I'd be up for the simple fix first :)
yes, I'm not thrilled about it, but no reason to make the users suffer while we refactor

nikomatsakis said:

(what calendar is the "async triage" meeting defined in?)

compiler team

nikomatsakis said:

yes, I'm not thrilled about it, but no reason to make the users suffer while we refactor

Yeah, that makes sense. Part of me says "let's think about intersection regions a little longer first" but I think getting a quick fix out makes more sense.
Changing the desugaring isn't wrong really, and I think it's a better solution than arbitrarily picking 'static
So yeah, I'm on board
I assume you've thought about this, but to double check: can this "leak" behavior we wouldn't want to keep later?
I'll be honest, I think the best way for me to contribute to polish is to mentor others on these kinds of issues

tmandry said:

I assume you've thought about this, but to double check: can this "leak" behavior we wouldn't want to keep later?

I believe not
but yeah, that's the question to think over some :)
so i'm going to put myself down as working with eholk on that :)

nikomatsakis said:

I'll be honest, I think the best way for me to contribute to polish is to mentor others on these kinds of issues

that's a great way to contribute :)

nikomatsakis said:

so i'm going to put myself down as working with eholk on that :)

Sounds good to me
okay
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Sprint goals
/me goes back to updating the doc
btw @tmandry
I volunteered us to read the RPITIDT writeup with @T-lang
I forget when :)
okay, seems like a good idea
• Mar 23
wednesdays are good for me
that's our goal, I assume "finish and publish that doc"
I don't imagine I'll have time for much else at least
that and the constrained impls RFC for me
that will be a very good sprint if we get those 2 things out
imo :)
yeah :)
@triagebot end-topic for when you're done updating the doc

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
okay

Sprint goals

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] (spastorino) Make RPIT use a type alias to a type defined in body's function
  • [ ] (tmandry) Post constrained impls RFC on the initiative repo
  • [ ] (tmandry) Post constrained impls RFC on the rfcs repo
  • [ ] (nikomatsakis/tmandry) Post "returning impl Trait in dyn" explainer
FYI, I've updated the calendar to have "Async reading club" and "Async triage" as distinct events
alternating every 2 weeks
thank you!
the starting time also needs to be updated
back to goals..

Polish

Goals:

  • [ ] (eholk) Finish writing up results from better-backtrace formatting

Issues: ([project board])

  • [ ] (tmandry) Review #93313
  • [ ] (tmandry) E0623 highlights wrong parameter in async fn #74256
    - [ ] Write a note explaining why the suggest_adding_lifetime_params suggestion is not firing on the async cases in the bug
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) Deref coercion does not work for some await returned values #83783
  • [ ] (eholk) Dropped variables still included in generator type #57478
    - [ ] Merge fixes for drop tracking ICEs
    - [ ] https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/93313
    - [ ] Once fixes merge, do crater run
    - [ ] If crater is okay, change default for -Zdrop-tracking

Tooling

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) help address "Awaitee field in async fns needs special name" debuginfo blocker for crashdump debugging

tmandry said:

the starting time also needs to be updated

do you mean ending time?
what did we decide?
no, decided to extend to 15 minutes earlier
I can also update it
done
I'm going to add RPITIDT writeup to the list, speaking of

@pnkfelix

help address "Awaitee field in async fns needs special name" debuginfo blocker for crashdump debugging

do you have specific ideas of what to do here?
cool

nikomatsakis said:

I'm going to add RPITIDT writeup to the list, speaking of

oh, and nrc's async I/O traits?
seems like we have quite the backlog :)
yes
I guess we should spend 5 minutes at the end of each meeting selecting the next one
yes, I have that in there
I also said that you + I can just "decide" if that is too annoying

nikomatsakis said:

pnkfelix

help address "Awaitee field in async fns needs special name" debuginfo blocker for crashdump debugging

do you have specific ideas of what to do here?

no, I need to read more

nikomatsakis said:

pnkfelix

help address "Awaitee field in async fns needs special name" debuginfo blocker for crashdump debugging

do you have specific ideas of what to do here?

I think you could move the awaitee to a temporary with a name like $awaitee at the beginning of the await desugaring
hmm
but for combinators and such you'll have to do something special
or maybe just something more general. like listing all the values they contain with types that impl Future
anyway, don't have to solve everything at once

tmandry said:

I think you could move the awaitee to a temporary with a name like $awaitee at the beginning of the await desugaring

I think this aligns with mw 's suggestion to "solution here is probably change the symbol chosen by the compiler to signal the purpose."
but I can see how it might not be quite that easy
unfortunately I don't even have a issue number linked for this
y'all I'm super excited about the async reading club
yeah.. the other thing you can do is put debuginfo metadata on the generator variant associated with that await point
it could point to the field being awaited, somehow
these are two ways of saying the same thing basically
@tmandry do you know if there's an issue filed about this? I guess I can try github search...
hmm I'm not sure there is
I have spent a fair amount of time thinking about this but never documented it. sorry

tmandry said:

yeah.. the other thing you can do is put debuginfo metadata on the generator variant associated with that await point

that's roughly as far as I got
ok.. we are out of time so I guess there's no point in doing a poll to end the meeting :)
thanks everyone
I've update the doc. I didn't achieve any of my goals but did make good progress on two of them. This sprint I've carried over last sprint's goals but cut one down to a sub-task
